Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Controlling Microstructure for Strong and Damage Tolerant Nanocrystalline Metals

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanocrystalline metals and alloys (polycrystals with grain sizes less than ~100 nm) offer a suite of appealing mechanical properties for structural applications, including high strength and hardness, enhanced fatigue resistance, and tribological robustness. These virtues derive from the large fraction of material that resides at the interfaces between neighboring crystals, known as grain boundaries. For these materials, this high fraction of interfacial volume can cause deleterious effects such as thermal instability and relatively poor damage tolerance. Many present and future applications of nanocrystalline metals such as robust coatings, electrical interconnects, micro- and nano-electro-mechanical systems, and soft magnets subject these materials to extreme mechanical duress, which can activate microstructural transformation and alter the beneficial materials properties. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports research centered on the concept that control of grain boundary chemistry in nanocrystalline alloys can be used to tailor the thermal and mechanical stability of nanocrystalline materials against grain boundary migration in extreme service environments. Control over this behavior can allow for unprecedented control of damage tolerance, thus enabling a novel and inexpensive structural materials design strategy.

In this research program, the investigators aim to control grain boundary chemistry in nanocrystalline alloys as a means to encode the onset of thermally- and mechanically-driven grain boundary migration under service conditions. In cases where extreme mechanical environments are encountered (e.g. at stress concentrations such as crack tips), stress-driven grain boundary migration can be triggered to respond to damage, endowing the material with damage tolerance. This dynamic material response is predicated on local stress triggers that drive microstructure transition and dissipate energy to mitigate catastrophic failure, allowing for both strength and toughness. The research will be accomplished via the following scientific and technical goals: (a) identify and characterize the mechanisms that lead to mechanically-induced grain boundary migration and grain growth, (b) identify and characterize the manner in which these mechanisms are influenced by grain boundary chemistry, (c) identify elements that will segregate to grain boundary and modulate thermal and stress-driven grain boundary migration, (d) synthesize nanocrystalline alloys with tailored grain boundary chemistry, and (e) perform material characterization and quantitative in situ mechanical testing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Key outcomes for the EAGER project are summarized below. 

  • Nanoindentation measurements indicate that sub-ablation-threshold fs-laser treatments cause a significant decrease in hardness in nanocrystalline alloys. These hardness changes are dramatic (up to 80% reduction) in the nanocrystalline alloys (Al-4.8 at%O, Q- and SC-CuZr) with very fine grain size (<50 nm), yet are negligible in the larger grain nanocrystalline sample (Al-0.8 at%O).  This strongly suggests that the laser deposits its energy preferentially at disordered grain boundary regions, while having minimal to no impact within the crystalline cores.
  • Our results and analyses show that the induced softening can be ascribed to the fs-laser interaction with grain boundary regions, due to structural and chemical heterogeneities, and cannot be understood through traditional coarsening, porosity, or segregation effects.
  • The magnitude of softening caused by the fs-laser is dependent upon the initial energetic state of the material ? samples with higher energy had a smaller magnitude softening prior to ablation, whereas samples near equilibrium had large tunability in hardness.
  • The softening induced by the fs-laser is fully recoverable upon annealing at low temperatures, suggesting that atomic motion at grain boundary regions (operative at such low temperatures) is responsible for both the softening and relaxation.
  • This study suggests that the similarities between nanocrystalline metals and amorphous alloys are vast, and that our understanding of mechanical behavior of nanocrystalline metals may be greatly informed by the metallic glass community. The application of processing strategies across disciplines, such as fs-laser processing, and material classes can be useful in broadening the tunability and functionality of nanocrystalline materials. We believe that the premise of structural rejuvenation of nanocrystalline metals and its impact on properties such as ductility and damage tolerance is a promising area for future research.
  • We employed Nanocrystalline Al85Ni10Ce5 samples prepared by sputter deposition exhibit an extremely fine and thermally stable nanocrystalline microstructure. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) investigations suggest that this alloys exhibit a 7.6 nm average grain size in the as-deposited condition, which evolves negligibly when annealed below 380℃, a homologous temperature of 0.7 Tm of pure Aluminum.
  • Ex-situ annealing experiments induce strong chemical segregation of the Ni and Ce to grain boundaries, evident in high angle annular dark field scanning transmission microscopy investigations. Annealing also promotes the formation of an amorphous intergranular film in the Ni and Ce rich grain boundary region, which dramatically affects the mechanical response.
  • Nanoindentation measurements indicate that the as-deposited hardness of the Al85Ni10Ce5 of 4.7 GPa is extremely high compared to existing nanocrystalline Aluminum alloys. Annealing at temperatures below 380℃ provides an additional 0.95 GPa increase in the hardness and 20 GPa increase in the modulus of the alloy, resulting in a maximum hardness of 5.6 GPa, unprecedented for a single phase nanocrystalline aluminum alloy.
  • The deformation morphology undergoes a dramatic transition from profuse strain localization, exhibited in the pile-up region during indentation, to more homogeneous plasticity after annealing below 380℃. This occurs concomitantly with the formation of an amorphous intergranular film, suggesting a mechanistic transition in the deformation due to the chemical evolution during annealing.
  • TEM investigations of indented regions of both the as-deposited and annealed samples suggest that the deformation is primarily accommodated through intragranular dislocation-based plasticity in the annealed condition, as opposed to the multitude of grain boundary mediated deformation mechanisms operative in the as-deposited sample as well as conventional nanocrystalline metals.
  • This study suggests that multicomponent nanocrystalline metals may be extremely promising for structural applications, and that our understanding of the effects of chemical segregation to grain boundaries is crucial for alloy design. We believe that the behavior observed in the Al85Ni10Ce5 alloy presented in this work provides significant insight into the segregation behavior in multicomponent nanocrystalline alloys, and may enable the design of nanocrystalline metals with exceptional ductility and damage tolerance ? a promising area for future research.

 

Our project provided key insights from the use of targeted synthesis and processing routes for nanocrystalline alloys to engineer the interfacial chemistry and state.  Our experiments suggest that the Al85Ni10Ce5 alloy investigated in this project exhibits a sub-10 nm grain size, high hardness (> 5.5 GPa) and excellent thermal stability (up to 0.7 Tm).  The Al85Ni10Ce5 alloy investigated also exhibits tailorable deformation behavior ? annealing induced chemical segregation causes a transition from pronounced shear localization in the as-deposited state to homogeneous plasticity after annealing. This behavior is unique from all previous investigations of FCC nanocrystalline metals, where low-temperature annealing causes increased strength while increasing the propensity for strain localization. In our opinion, these results establish a new paradigm of grain boundary engineering ? namely, that the deformation behavior can be tailored through alloying elements with a high propensity for segregation, as well as elastic mismatch, providing increased strength and mitigating long range plastic localization.

Image
  • Synthesis of a ternary nanocrystalline Al alloy with Ni and Ce causes co-segregation to grain boundaries. Annealing at moderate temperatures promotes the formation of amorphous intergranular films, which cause dramatic changes in hardness and shear localization phenomena.
    Glenn Balbus, Fulin Wang, Dan Gianola
    Copyrighted
    Daniel S Gianola
    Segregation engineering in Al-Ni-Ce
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Key outcomes for the EAGER project are summarized below. Nanoindentation measurements indicate that sub-ablation-threshold fs-laser treatments cause a significant decrease in hardness in nanocrystalline alloys. These hardness changes are dramatic (up to 80% reduction) in the nanocrystalline alloys (Al-4.8 at%O, Q- and SC-CuZr) with very fine grain size (<50 nm), yet are negligible in the larger grain nanocrystalline sample (Al-0.8 at%O). This strongly suggests that the laser deposits its energy preferentially at disordered grain boundary regions, while having minimal to no impact within the crystalline cores. Our results and analyses show that the induced softening can be ascribed to the fs-laser interaction with grain boundary regions, due to structural and chemical heterogeneities, and cannot be understood through traditional coarsening, porosity, or segregation effects. The magnitude of softening caused by the fs-laser is dependent upon the initial energetic state of the material ? samples with higher energy had a smaller magnitude softening prior to ablation, whereas samples near equilibrium had large tunability in hardness. The softening induced by the fs-laser is fully recoverable upon annealing at low temperatures, suggesting that atomic motion at grain boundary regions (operative at such low temperatures) is responsible for both the softening and relaxation. This study suggests that the similarities between nanocrystalline metals and amorphous alloys are vast, and that our understanding of mechanical behavior of nanocrystalline metals may be greatly informed by the metallic glass community. The application of processing strategies across disciplines, such as fs-laser processing, and material classes can be useful in broadening the tunability and functionality of nanocrystalline materials. We believe that the premise of structural rejuvenation of nanocrystalline metals and its impact on properties such as ductility and damage tolerance is a promising area for future research. We employed Nanocrystalline Al85Ni10Ce5 samples prepared by sputter deposition exhibit an extremely fine and thermally stable nanocrystalline microstructure. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) investigations suggest that this alloys exhibit a 7.6 nm average grain size in the as-deposited condition, which evolves negligibly when annealed below 380℃, a homologous temperature of 0.7 Tm of pure Aluminum. Ex-situ annealing experiments induce strong chemical segregation of the Ni and Ce to grain boundaries, evident in high angle annular dark field scanning transmission microscopy investigations. Annealing also promotes the formation of an amorphous intergranular film in the Ni and Ce rich grain boundary region, which dramatically affects the mechanical response. Nanoindentation measurements indicate that the as-deposited hardness of the Al85Ni10Ce5 of 4.7 GPa is extremely high compared to existing nanocrystalline Aluminum alloys. Annealing at temperatures below 380℃ provides an additional 0.95 GPa increase in the hardness and 20 GPa increase in the modulus of the alloy, resulting in a maximum hardness of 5.6 GPa, unprecedented for a single phase nanocrystalline aluminum alloy. The deformation morphology undergoes a dramatic transition from profuse strain localization, exhibited in the pile-up region during indentation, to more homogeneous plasticity after annealing below 380℃. This occurs concomitantly with the formation of an amorphous intergranular film, suggesting a mechanistic transition in the deformation due to the chemical evolution during annealing. TEM investigations of indented regions of both the as-deposited and annealed samples suggest that the deformation is primarily accommodated through intragranular dislocation-based plasticity in the annealed condition, as opposed to the multitude of grain boundary mediated deformation mechanisms operative in the as-deposited sample as well as conventional nanocrystalline metals. This study suggests that multicomponent nanocrystalline metals may be extremely promising for structural applications, and that our understanding of the effects of chemical segregation to grain boundaries is crucial for alloy design. We believe that the behavior observed in the Al85Ni10Ce5 alloy presented in this work provides significant insight into the segregation behavior in multicomponent nanocrystalline alloys, and may enable the design of nanocrystalline metals with exceptional ductility and damage tolerance ? a promising area for future research. Our project provided key insights from the use of targeted synthesis and processing routes for nanocrystalline alloys to engineer the interfacial chemistry and state. Our experiments suggest that the Al85Ni10Ce5 alloy investigated in this project exhibits a sub-10 nm grain size, high hardness (> 5.5 GPa) and excellent thermal stability (up to 0.7 Tm). The Al85Ni10Ce5 alloy investigated also exhibits tailorable deformation behavior ? annealing induced chemical segregation causes a transition from pronounced shear localization in the as-deposited state to homogeneous plasticity after annealing. This behavior is unique from all previous investigations of FCC nanocrystalline metals, where low-temperature annealing causes increased strength while increasing the propensity for strain localization. In our opinion, these results establish a new paradigm of grain boundary engineering ? namely, that the deformation behavior can be tailored through alloying elements with a high propensity for segregation, as well as elastic mismatch, providing increased strength and mitigating long range plastic localization.
